comments.body:
Added these because CircleCI had a very old stale `master` branch from months ago due to its caching of the git repo. The other CIs never needed them.

Turns out there is a simple strategy to workaround the caching on CircleCI. Implemented in PR ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/1467 ). This should make this strategy more robust to changes on the remote.

Though should add this general CircleCI strategy may fail if `master` has already converted those recipes. This is because CircleCI does not merge with `master`, but works on the PR tip. To fix that case, we can actually just merge with `master` ourselves, which will clear the converted recipes from our history automatically. PR ( https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/pull/1486 ) will do exactly that.

comments.body:
@pelson, would it be alright if we include OpenGL support on Linux? Both Mac and Windows already have this. However, Linux is a simple package away from having this support.

Just like we have X11 to support Qt, it would be nice to have OpenGL to support a variety of other graphics programs. Does this sound ok to you?
I am OK with that, but we merge this we should updated the Docker image and remove this from here.

Should we move all the X11 stuff into the `Dockerfile`? There was some discussion about adding `yum` dependencies to recipes at one point. That may actually be better in some ways. The main reason being if one needs to build a Docker image, they will know what needs to be `yum` installed or not.
See this issue ( https://github.com/conda-forge/conda-forge.github.io/issues/82 ) to help form a spec on handling `yum` in a standard per recipe manner.
In the meantime, I usual handle this by hacking a similar script in the feedstock to get this behavior. See this [example](https://github.com/conda-forge/qimage2ndarray-feedstock/pull/1/files).

Per your suggestion @ocefpaf. We are adding this to the container in this PR ( https://github.com/pelson/Obvious-CI/pull/63 ). Though we really should work on a better way of doing this that is a bit more transparent to the user and requires only local changes to the recipe itself.
